page.title: 07Hopton Hall
page.content: Hopton Hall is the largest house in the village.It was built in the 1560's but has been altered a great deal since then.The middle portion of the house was once an open courtyard now closed with a flat arched roof.Built mainly of brick it has always been the home of the Gell progeny.The early Gells derived there wealth from the lead mining industry.It was Sir Philip Gell who had the road 'Via Gellia' made in 1790 to transport the coal to the Cromford Canal. It is thought that at one time Mary Queen of Scots slept in a four poster bed made for Sir John Gell.The Gell dynasty endowed the present primary school in Carsington(now church aided) and built almshouses in Hopton and Wirksworth. All in all the family of Gell were patricians in the district although they are now less significant.
